(7) Some studies have raised the question about the ability of ITV to
create adequate student-teacher interaction. This does not mean that
such rapport cannot be developed, A recently announced "Teletest
Communications System" facilitates active contact between video
instructor and .student. This system has already been approved
by California's State Department of Education. Under this new
method the student receives the means with which to respond
immediately to questions from the television teacher; the student
also receives instantly, information as to the correctness of his
replies. Furthermore, the equipment includes electronic scoring
and tabulating devices which, (a) completely eliminate tedious
and time consuming corrections of papers, and (b) do away with
other bookkeeping tasks which teachers must normally perform in
connection with testing and grading.
(8) Lack of student-teacher rapport under ITV has caused many teachers
to view this medium as a threat to the small class, and hence to
democratic education itself. That position rests on the assumption
that basic values can best be imparted through a close physical
and psychological relationship between teacher and student. ITV
proponents, imbued by a missionary zeal of their own, have done
little to overcome such objections. Thus a certain amount of
unnecessary suspicion as to the real motives of ITV's advocates
has been aroused. Yet it is becoming increasingly evident that
